src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3814/11327428724_79899c3138_o.jpg" width="545" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;i&gt;NYC, coming soon to Archer &amp;amp; Fable's bedroom&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;I've&lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2012/12/totw-ellalou-recycled-clutch-giveaway.html" target="_blank"&gt; posted&lt;/a&gt; about &lt;a href="http://www.shopellalou.com/" target="_blank"&gt;Ella Lou&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2012/05/thing-of-week-ella-lou-turkish-towels.html" target="_blank"&gt; before&lt;/a&gt;. Her&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2012/05/thing-of-week-ella-lou-turkish-towels.html" target="_blank"&gt;pestamels &lt;/a&gt;are my absolute favorite and her &lt;a href="http://www.shopellalou.com/Handbags-and-clutches-s/1876.htm" target="_blank"&gt;clutches are to die for &lt;/a&gt;but THESE, oh man, THESE are exactly what I've been looking for for the kids' rooms and HOLD ON, IT'S WASHABLE? (Cough, Ikea playmat that gets gross in three minutes, cough.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Two of our four are urban planning nuts. Archer still plays daily with his&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2012/03/thing-of-week-tomica-train-tracks-city.html" target="_blank"&gt;Tomica set&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;on the daily,&amp;nbsp;Fable every so often joining him.&amp;nbsp;Revi is also super into building train sets. (Bo really enjoys breaking them down while pretending she's a frog.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Anyway, these SF + NYC playmats are fresh off the presses and sure to be a huge hit for the child in your life that loves to play AKA pretty much everyone who exists.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.shopellalou.com/Wanderlust-City-Playmats-s/1890.htm" title="Playmats01 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="Playmats01" height="221" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7306/11330554043_8c6cfea782.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11330552273/" title="Playmats02 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="Playmats02" height="221" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2809/11330552273_865244779d.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Ella Lou is an amazing company founded by an incredible woman named Lindsay who is just the kindest most generous human being/mama/entrepreneur you can imagine. Her products are beautifully made and ethically produced and lifelong. (You can read more about how Ella Lou gives back, &lt;a href="https://www.shopellalou.com/Articles.asp?ID=250" target="_blank"&gt;here.&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.shopellalou.com/Wanderlust-City-Playmats-s/1890.htm" title="PbLOjg2K2YZKmo5ak3W894T1uUg6oHipFlDfvelnTEg by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="PbLOjg2K2YZKmo5ak3W894T1uUg6oHipFlDfvelnTEg" height="338" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3773/11327483323_9b255f5a94.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;i&gt;San Francisco, coming soon to Bo and Revi's nursery&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;This week thanks to Lindsay and Ella Lou I'm giving away a &lt;a href="http://www.shopellalou.com/Wanderlust-City-Playmats-s/1890.htm" target="_blank"&gt;playmat + wooden transportation toy&lt;/a&gt; of your choice. (Pick between San Francisco +&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.shopellalou.com/Playthings-Red-Cable-Car-Wood-Push-Toy-p/usatoy-cc.htm" target="_blank"&gt;Cable Car&lt;/a&gt; or NYC +&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.shopellalou.com/Playthings-Yellow-Taxi-Wood-Push-Toy-p/usatoy-ta.htm" target="_blank"&gt;Taxi Cab&lt;/a&gt;!) To win? Leave a comment below. I'll pick one random winner next Thursday 12/19. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Shop between now and 12/31 and receive 15% off your order with code GGC15. Good luck to all and happy shopping!&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/4464855730277631689/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=4464855730277631689' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/4464855730277631689'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/4464855730277631689'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/12/playmats-that-give-back-giveaway.html' title='Playmats that Give Back (&amp; Giveaway!)'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-5933417787671430097</id><published>2013-12-11T13:22:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2013-12-11T14:09:32.172-08:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='eat well'/><title type='text'>Eat Well: Nuts for You</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;The following post was written by my mom, WWW. Thanks, mom!&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11329693086/" title="IMG_1124 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_1124" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5515/11329693086_3f075e25f6_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;My friend, Lorraine, gave us some amazing nuts the other day…so amazing that I thought you all might like the recipe as a treat for your family or as another idea for edible Christmas presents.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;These nuts might be a good compromise if you thought my &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/11/the-gift-that-keeps-on-sprouting.html" target="_blank"&gt;sprout/salt idea&lt;/a&gt; a little TOO healthy but still wanted to give something besides &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2010/12/eat-not-so-well-because-whatever-who.html" target="_blank"&gt;candy&lt;/a&gt; or &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2011/12/eat-well-happy-gluten-free-holidays.html" target="_blank"&gt;cookies&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;They would also be a great bring-along for Christmas parties. &lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;A note about nuts.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;I buy my nuts in bulk, but I ALWAYS taste them before I buy them. Nuts go rancid very quickly and there is nothing worse than making a lovely nut recipe only to find the nuts to be bad.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;Even packaged nuts can be off (I had a bad batch of packaged pecans the other day), so make sure you taste them before you put all of the time (and money) into cooking them.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;I speak from experience here.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;I have been burned before and now I am SUPER careful!&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;!--[if gte mso 9]&gt;&lt;xml&gt; &lt;o:DocumentProperties&gt; &lt;w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"    UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 6"/&gt;  &lt;w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="19" SemiHidden="false" QFormat="true" Name="Book Title"/&gt;  &lt;w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography"/&gt;  &lt;w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/&gt; &lt;/w:LatentStyles&gt;&lt;/xml&gt;&lt;![endif]--&gt; &lt;!--[if gte mso 10]&gt;&lt;style&gt; /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable 	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal"; 	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0; 	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0; 	mso-style-noshow:yes; 	mso-style-priority:99; 	mso-style-parent:""; 	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt; 	mso-para-margin-top:0in; 	mso-para-margin-right:0in; 	mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt; 	mso-para-margin-left:0in; 	mso-pagination:widow-orphan; 	font-size:12.0pt; 	font-family:Cambria; 	mso-ascii-font-family:Cambria; 	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; 	mso-hansi-font-family:Cambria; 	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; 	mso-fareast-language:JA;} &lt;/style&gt;&lt;![endif]--&gt;   &lt;!--StartFragment--&gt; &lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;The original recipe for Spicy Nuts came from&lt;a href="http://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/emeril-lagasse/spiced-nuts-recipe2/index.html" target="_blank"&gt; Emeril Lagasse&lt;/a&gt;.&amp;nbsp; Lorraine modified the recipe a bit after reading people’s suggestions and then I changed a few more things.&amp;nbsp; Here is my version of the recipe&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;!--EndFragment--&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"&gt;Sweet and Spicy Nuts&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"&gt;(Modified from Emeril Lagasse Spiced Nuts)&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;b style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;4 cups unsalted raw nuts (any combination of walnuts, pecans, cashews, almonds, or hazelnuts)&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;4 T unsalted butter (could substitute coconut oil or Earth Balance)&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;1 t. ground cumin&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;1/2 t. cayenne pepper (more if you like things really spicy!)&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;1 t. ground cinnamon&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;½ t. salt&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;½ cup packed brown sugar&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;1 T water&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11329706306/" title="IMG_1094 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_1094" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3793/11329706306_45214eeb8b.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;In large heavy skillet (not aluminum), melt butter and add nuts.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11329634895/" title="IMG_1095 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_1095" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3827/11329634895_b5d9c3ec86.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Cook over medium heat until nuts are toasted, about 4-5 minutes. Add spices, sugar, and water and cook until sugar is melted, about 1-2 minutes.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Turn out onto aluminum foil lined baking sheet, breaking into clumps as desired.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;When cool, store in airtight container.&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11329696696/" title="IMG_1099 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_1099" height="375" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7339/11329696696_dd10ae07ae.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;You can use almonds, pecans, walnuts, cashews, or hazelnuts.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;The walnuts and pecans, because of their nooks and crannies, hold onto the syrup best, but a mixture of nuts is lovely.&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11329725804/" title="IMG_1129 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_1129" height="375" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2841/11329725804_c0c689c3ac.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;Enjoy!&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;Love,&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;!--[if gte mso 9]&gt;&lt;xml&gt; Are you warm enough?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"Yup.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"But it's 39 degrees out here."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"So?"&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"It's freezing. It's abnormally freezing and you're not used to this kind of freezing and aren't you freezing?"&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"No."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Where's your coat?"&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"I took it off."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"But it's so cold!"&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"I'm hot."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Come on."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"What? I'm not cold at all. It isn't cold."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"How can you say that? I have seventeen layers on and I'm still freezing."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Then&lt;i&gt; you &lt;/i&gt;should wear a coat."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"I am! And a hat and boots. And a scarf."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Here. I'll put my hood up. There. Happy?"&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Yes."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Okay."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Okay."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11293203213/" title="photo (38) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (38)" height="800" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5523/11293203213_9bd16880ac_c.jpg" width="534" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;I trek back into the house under the weight of forty-seven blankets, nine pairs of snow boots and sixteen ski masks.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;Fable rolls up her sleeves.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/7887044452714098462/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' '/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-4709383138567980706</id><published>2013-12-10T09:12:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2013-12-10T09:12:38.837-08:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='mix tape'/><title type='text'>188/100</title><content type='html'>We've been looking forward to DJ Earworm's &lt;a href="http://djearworm.com/united-state-of-pop" target="_blank"&gt;"United State of Pop"&lt;/a&gt; and&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://giftofocpd.com/2013/12/03/pop-danthology-2013/" target="_blank"&gt;Daniel Kim's Pop Danthology 2013&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;(I posted&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2012/12/145100.html" target="_blank"&gt;his 2012 mix&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;last year) for months and now they're here and we can't stop dancing. And dancing. (And also dancing.) I love me a good mash-up and DJ Earworm and Daniel Kim are at the top of their game. Party on, Wayne.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="-webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; color: black; font-family: Times; font-size: medium; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-align: center; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: auto; word-spacing: 0px;"&gt;&lt;div style="margin: 0px;"&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/ZGRQKKaox5Q?rel=0" width="560"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/HJMapA8WgYw?rel=0" width="560"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;188. Pop Danthology by: &lt;a href="http://giftofocpd.com/2013/12/03/pop-danthology-2013/" target="_blank"&gt;Daniel Kim&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;+ United States of Pop 2013 by:&lt;a href="http://djearworm.com/" target="_blank"&gt; DJ Earworm&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div&gt;P.S. The 2013 Pop Danthology is available to download for free,&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://giftofocpd.com/2013/12/03/pop-danthology-2013/" target="_blank"&gt;here.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;i&gt;Moonwalk Roger Rabbit Running Man out,&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/4709383138567980706/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=4709383138567980706' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/4709383138567980706'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/4709383138567980706'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/12/188100.html' title='188/100'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media='http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/' url='http://img.youtube.com/vi/ZGRQKKaox5Q/default.jpg' height='72' width='72'/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-2166051364201249254</id><published>2013-12-09T09:36:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2013-12-10T09:45:29.119-08:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='she section'/><title type='text'>The Mother Co &amp; Staying Safe without Fear</title><content type='html'>&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;I met Abbie and Sam, founders of &lt;a href="http://www.themotherco.com/" target="_blank"&gt;The Mother Company&lt;/a&gt;, over the summer and was blown away by their awesome. (ED: If you're unfamiliar with &lt;a href="http://www.themotherco.com/" target="_blank"&gt;&amp;nbsp;The Mother Co&lt;/a&gt;, I highly recommend you check them out. Great parenting resource.) Over a recent lunch,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;Abbie and I got to talking about stranger danger/fear mongering/all of the things I wrote about &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/11/talking-to-strangers.html" target="_blank"&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;. She then told me about &lt;a href="http://www.rubysstudio.com/products/safety-show-dvd" target="_blank"&gt;Ruby's Studio: The Safety Show&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;and EMPOWERING children to listen to their "uh-oh feeling" instead of scaring them away from adults/human contact/life.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222; text-align: center;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;(Amen.)&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br class="Apple-interchange-newline" /&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="360" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/jZ8b18jNLxA?rel=0" style="color: #222222; font-style: italic;" width="480"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;I recommend their program with five thousand stars for parents and educators looking for an assist in the safety conversation. Ruby goes "there" in a way that isn't scary and I am so appreciative that there are women like Abbie and Sam in this space. (I get pitched the most insane fear-mongery "the world is out to get your children!" stuff ALL DAY LONG so talking to Abbie and Sam is a breath of fresh high-fives.) &amp;nbsp;Anyway. Mother Company 4 prez. Let's talk safety.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11240902463/" title="Ab and Sam under RS sign by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="Ab and Sam under RS sign" height="800" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2851/11240902463_7451292864_c.jpg" width="534" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;Abbie &amp;amp; Sam: founders of The Mother Co&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;GGC: Why did you decide to do a show on safety?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Abbie:&lt;/b&gt; Because as a parent, I needed one. When my daughter was really young,&amp;nbsp;I worried about her safety and wondered how to talk to her about safety and even&amp;nbsp;how to teach her how to be safe. I knew I couldn't always&amp;nbsp;be around her and didn’t know where to start without creeping her out or having a really icky discussion I wanted to avoid. &amp;nbsp;I went to a great parenting talk by a nationally acclaimed children’s safety expert,&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.themotherco.com/2013/10/top-four-safety-tips-for-kids/" style="color: #1155cc;" target="_blank"&gt;Pattie Fitzgerald&lt;/a&gt;, who basically taught me how to talk to my daughter about her safety by&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;i style="color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;empowering&lt;/i&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;her. &amp;nbsp;I left that parenting talk needing a totally entertaining show for kids that would be a tool for parents - that complemented Pattie’s wise approach. &amp;nbsp;I wanted a hero in the media - a modern day Mister Rogers mixed with the magic of Mary Poppins - who could reiterate the safety (and social and emotional) messages that would help my daughter become a&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;i style="color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;good person&lt;/i&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white;"&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11292554543/" title="Screen_Shot_2013-11-19_at_11.54.06_AM_large by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="Screen_Shot_2013-11-19_at_11.54.06_AM_large" height="480" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7350/11292554543_00ee06e1a5.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;Media is such a powerful educational tool when used well. But all the only video out there for kids on safety actually overwhelmed and scared my daughter. Not helpful. &amp;nbsp;I knew a smart, gentle, beautifully produced show was what we needed--and I vowed to make that show six years ago to help the millions of parents who shared my concern for our childrens' safety and who also wanted all the help we could get in instilling that wisdom in our kids. I’m proud that&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;i style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.rubysstudio.com/collections/dvds/products/safety-show-dvd" style="color: #1155cc;" target="_blank"&gt;The Safety Show&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;is all that I had hoped for and now thousands of other parents (and their kids!) are loving it too.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;b style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;GGC: What are your feelings on "stranger danger”?&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;b style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Abbie:&lt;/b&gt; There are many things misguided about talking to kids about “stranger danger.” The unfortunate fact is that strangers, for the most part, aren’t the ones that most often pose a threat to children. Research shows that 90% of the harm done to children is by&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;i style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;people they know.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;Also, it’s misleading since we all live in a society where we have to talk to strangers all day - people in elevators, at stores, at school - interacting with them makes for a more pleasant world. &amp;nbsp;Additionally, “stranger danger” gives children the fearful sense that there is some kind of “boogieman” out there to get them. &amp;nbsp;But, again, the people who can cause harm don’t often look like they can. Predators are generally likable people with techniques that make both parents and kids trust them - there are almost never “boogiemen” (think of all those “trusted” examples in the news of teachers, coaches, boy scout leaders, and clergyman).&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;And finally, if children get lost - and 7 out of 10 of them will get lost in their lifetimes- they need to know to ask a “stranger” - a mom with kids, for example - for help and know that is a safe choice, even though she is technically a stranger. &amp;nbsp;With&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;i style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.rubysstudio.com/collections/dvds/products/safety-show-dvd" style="color: #1155cc;" target="_blank"&gt;The Safety Show&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;, we at The Mother Company feel its better to empower children around their safety and have them trust their “uh-oh feeling.” &amp;nbsp;Our bodies tell us when something doesn’t feel right and we should encourage our children to listen to that instinct.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11240906323/" title="RS102-Credits-76 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="RS102-Credits-76" height="281" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3816/11240906323_d3c86e3392.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;b style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;GGC: How does The Safety Show empower parents/educators AS WELL as children?&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #007316;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Sam: &lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;i style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;The Safety Show&lt;/i&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;empowers parents, educators and children with knowledge and a positive approach to safety (rather than a fearful one). &amp;nbsp;The truth is that it can really be hard for parents and educators to talk to kids about safety: &amp;nbsp;we don't want to terrify kids and encourage them to live in fear - and some of the safety related topics can be uncomfortable to talk about, especially around safe touches and bodily safety. &amp;nbsp;So with&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;i style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.rubysstudio.com/collections/dvds/products/safety-show-dvd" style="color: #1155cc;" target="_blank"&gt;The Safety Show&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;, children gain empowering tips, tools and language around their personal safety without any scare tactics or "ick" factor. &amp;nbsp;We worked with Pattie's safety curriculum and came up with gentle, engaging and fun stories to explore what we feel are the four most important safety tools for adults to address with their kids:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #0f61c8;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;1.) "The Uh-Oh Feeling": &amp;nbsp;this is the internal barometer inside all of us that tells us that something doesn't feel safe. &amp;nbsp;It's important to validate our kids' "uh-oh feelings" because then they will learn to trust their instincts and get out of harm's way.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #0f61c8;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;2.) "Check First": &amp;nbsp;This just means that your kid should check first with you (or another safe adult, like a teacher or caregiver) whenever going anywhere or doing anything unexpected. &amp;nbsp;If checking first becomes a habit, even in perfectly safe situations, they will be less likely to find themselves alone in an unsafe situation.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #0f61c8;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;3.) "Be the&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zAALZxa6NCw&amp;amp;list=TLjIEFyGKr2YIGkCd1DP-vo8YSF8k-_hHO" style="background-color: white; color: #1155cc;" target="_blank"&gt;Boss of Your Body&lt;/a&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;" -- This phrase empowers kids to say "no" to any kind of touch that doesn't feel right. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br class="Apple-interchange-newline" /&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="360" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/zAALZxa6NCw?rel=0" style="background-color: white; color: #222222; font-style: italic;" width="480"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #0f61c8;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;4.) "Get Smart About Getting Lost" -- As Abbie mentioned, getting lost will happen in most kids' lifetimes, so it's important to have a plan. &amp;nbsp;Memorizing your safe adult's phone number is a great thing (&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.themotherco.com/2013/10/video-how-to-make-a-safety-wristband/" style="background-color: white; color: #1155cc;" target="_blank"&gt;and our craft in "The Safety Show" is all about that&lt;/a&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;) and learning to find a "mom with kids" is likely to be their safest bet.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #0f61c8;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;The show also provides our "Pop-Up Parenting" feature in the DVD menu, where Pattie offers safety tips for parents throughout the show in little subtitles at the bottom of the screen. &amp;nbsp;It's totally optional, but we figure it's an added bonus for parents and educators to gain a little more knowledge as they watch the show with their kids.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11240800395/" title="sch-P120613_069 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="sch-P120613_069" height="333" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2808/11240800395_867b246d95.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;The Mother Co is offering 20% off &lt;a href="http://www.rubysstudio.com/collections/dvds/products/safety-show-dvd" target="_blank"&gt;Ruby's Studio: The Safety Show&lt;/a&gt; and all Mother Co items (that aren't already on sale!) with code GGC20. For more on The Safety Show go&lt;a href="http://www.rubysstudio.com/collections/dvds/products/safety-show-dvd" target="_blank"&gt; here.&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white;"&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/2166051364201249254/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=2166051364201249254' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/2166051364201249254'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/2166051364201249254'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/12/the-mother-co-staying-safe-without-fear.html' title='The Mother Co &amp; Staying Safe without Fear'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><media:thumbnail xmlns:media='http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/' url='http://img.youtube.com/vi/jZ8b18jNLxA/default.jpg' height='72' width='72'/><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-8602816916148943273</id><published>2013-12-06T09:51:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2013-12-06T11:06:53.512-08:00</updated><title type='text'>BLD: Mirrors of Krizia Sweater Dress (&amp; Vintage Christian Dior Giveaway)</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11225801904/" title="IMG_0460 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_0460" height="332" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7452/11225801904_348735b673.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;Hi, I've decided to bring back Gone Style as a monthly post option. Mainly because you asked and I thought it would be fun to talk about clothes sometimes because I like clothes and I like talking about clothes and linking to stores that rule around the Internet and Los Angeles.&amp;nbsp;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;Plus, I get to hang out with one of my best pals, &lt;a href="http://www.histyley.com/" target="_blank"&gt;EvaLotta who shoots HiStyley&lt;/a&gt; and&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;makes me feel like I'm at 9th grade sleepover when we're together. (She shot the below photos that do not look like they were taken on a cell phone.) Thank you, Eva.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The concept for the "BLD" challenge is simple: One piece styled three ways a la Breakfast (coffee/school drop-off/casual am living), Lunch (meeting with colleague/friend/self) and Dinner (date night/girl's night/holiday party/get some). I'm starting with myself and next month will feature someone else and so forth... that's the plan, anyway. Every piece has three act potential. BLD 4 lyf.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Sweater dresses are on my top five timeless staples list that I carry inside my brain when I am in the market for something to purchase for my person. My sweater dresses are beloved and bear the bruises of a life well spilled on. They are also warm enough to wear without layering in the fall/winter here in LA, so no need for a coat which takes up way too much space in a bag that is more often than not overflowing with items.&amp;nbsp;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;(Although... it is very cold for LA right now. &amp;nbsp;As cold as it gets, hence the rat problem that is now resolved, thank goodness. &amp;nbsp;Knocking on wood right now with my foot.)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Today's post features one of my favorite items c/o&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.riceandbeansvintage.com/" target="_blank"&gt;Rice and Beans Vintage, THE destination for designer vintage, especially handbags (her Chanels are BEYOND.)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.riceandbeansvintage.com/products/vintage-80s-krizia-wool-angora-red-sweater-dress-w-foxes-as-seen-on-mary-kate-olsen" target="_blank"&gt;The (Mirrors by Krizia) fox dress&lt;/a&gt; was a SLAM DUNK in my soul for many reasons, one of them being its resemblance to, well, a wolf... which gives me a sort of name pride fierceness* that doesn't happen if, say, a cat or a bird or a mustache graphic is involved.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: large;"&gt;Breakfast:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;bunched up with a beanie, cut-offs over tights and moto boots:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11062299925/" title="IMG_0306 (1) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_0306 (1)" height="800" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2833/11062299925_1a8019e21a_c.jpg" width="534" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: start;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;Moto Boots: Rag &amp;amp; Bone&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: start;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;Glasses: Novelty shop, fitted with lenses c/o my optometrist&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: start;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;Bag: Kooba bag held together with super glue&lt;br /&gt;lip color: Viva Glam II by MAC&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11062539043/" title="IMG_0188 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_0188" height="800" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3722/11062539043_8d15ff8eca_c.jpg" width="534" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;ED: These photos were taken in front of Alfred Coffee which is a super chic little cafe on Melrose Place. Great coffee and fun place to meet up with pals.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: large;"&gt;Lunch: (Hal took these.)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;tucked in w/ blazer, boyfriend jeans + booties:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11225897605/" title="photo (36) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (36)" height="800" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7424/11225897605_6841cdd8c3_c.jpg" width="534" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div /&gt;Booties: nicole&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11225865195/" title="photo (34) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img today's post is featuring the badassness that is Rice &amp;amp; Beans Vintage (I die for &lt;a I mean)&amp;nbsp;and Sarah (who owns Rice and Beans) is so beyond generous, I am pleased as punch to offer you fine folks a chance to win this AMAZING vintage Christian Dior (circa 1970s) &lt;a href="http://www.riceandbeansvintage.com/collections/vintage-designer-handbags/products/dior-signature-handbag-or-clutch" target="_blank"&gt;handbag/clutch, a $400 value&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11063355313/" title="IMG_3254 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_3254" height="333" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3765/11063355313_e166546b12.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I mean...&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11063406393/" title="IMG_3255 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_3255" height="333" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5491/11063406393_6e743031a4.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Mint condish much?&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11063334796/" title="IMG_3256 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_3256" height="333" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7346/11063334796_a615f444b1.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Ahjahkjshadkja&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;To win? It's me again. (Whenever I attempt an Eat Well post I feel like I'm stealing my mom's car or something. Like, WOOO! I HAVE A FAKE ID LET'S HIT UP REVOLUCION!)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;This is actually a follow up to my &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/11/eat-well-go-to-lunch-salad.html" target="_blank"&gt;go-to lunch salad post&lt;/a&gt; and I figured, since this is the time of year where we have little time/many boxes of treats in the pantry, I'd post another super simple easy healthy quick delicious filling feel good salad recipe (recipe?) which is more or less what Hal and I eat for dinner every single night. A pile of greens covered with stuff.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div&gt;Here is what you need to make such a thing:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11224346176/" title="photo (27) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (27)" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3698/11224346176_7cd6791104_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Bag of herb salad mix from Trader Joes (if you do not have a TJs, you can use any kind of greens but please add dill and spinach leaves to the mix if you can. The dill is VERY IMPORTANT because dill + brown lentils = the perfect complement.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Pre-made lentils. (I also buy these at Trader Joes. Actually, Hal does. He does the household grocery shopping. They are a timesaver/lifesaver/dietary staple in our house.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11224321804/" title="photo (30) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (30)" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3721/11224321804_72c0dc2e86_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Artichoke hearts and/or hearts of palm OR garbanzo beans + avocado OR goat cheese and cranberries (pictured above).&lt;br /&gt;- Extra Virgin Olive Oil + Balsamic Vinegar&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;- Seasoning. If possible,&lt;a href="http://www.etsy.com/shop/VitalSalts?ref=search_shop_redirect" target="_blank"&gt; this&lt;/a&gt;, because there is nothing better in all the land. (My mom has &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/03/eat-well-gigande-beans-magical-fruit.html" target="_blank"&gt;written about it before&lt;/a&gt;. It's avail at her Farmer's Market and online, &lt;a href="http://www.etsy.com/shop/VitalSalts?ref=search_shop_redirect" target="_blank"&gt;here.)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11224337966/" title="photo (29) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (29)" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3699/11224337966_5b1f2fd152_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;(&lt;a href="http://www.amazon.com/Trader-Joes-Seasoning-Everything-Peppercorns/dp/B0078HYOFK" target="_blank"&gt;This one &lt;/a&gt;comes in second place.)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11224303265/" title="photo (31) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (31)" height="500" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2857/11224303265_6a073cab34.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;ED: Use as many greens as you can fit on the plate. Portion control does not apply when it comes to green leafy things.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;ED #2: Bo and Revi will eat this salad. Fable and Archer will not because they are "allergic to salad, gosh."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;ED #3: xoxoxo.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/3750636846875824666/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=3750636846875824666' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/3750636846875824666'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/3750636846875824666'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/12/eat-well-go-to-dinner-salad.html' title='Eat Well: Go-To Dinner Salad '/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-9118727268320673291</id><published>2013-12-04T13:44:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2013-12-04T13:44:21.108-08:00</updated><title type='text'>Whoa. </title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11211330474/" title="p5 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="p5" height="624" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2852/11211330474_7ba5f9cc29_z.jpg" width="502" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;It just came to my attention that &lt;a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gillian_Lynne" target="_blank"&gt;Gillian Lynne&lt;/a&gt; mentioned in &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/12/tiny-and-not-so-tiny-dancers.html" target="_blank"&gt;yesterday's post&lt;/a&gt; (via &lt;a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/ken_robinson_says_schools_kill_creativity.html" target="_blank"&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;) was one of the women featured in Fabulous Fashionistas, &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/11/its-i-suppose-more-adventurous.html" target="_blank"&gt;the BBC program I posted two weeks back&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Thank you, Rachel for pointing this out in the comments. It completely blew my mind and made my week.&amp;nbsp;&lt;span style="text-align: center;"&gt;So did this because THAT SPIRIT. I want to listen to her speak forever:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/CX_O3HHYB_k?rel=0" width="560"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"It's not enough to go on stage and be good... you have to do something with the air. You have to make it wondrous..."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11211341646/" title="p1 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="p1" height="598" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7299/11211341646_e243494149_o.jpg" width="456" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11211449943/" title="cp8 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="cp8" height="582" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5499/11211449943_b5b5c568ba_o.jpg" width="455" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11211327295/" title="cp10 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="cp10" height="600" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5484/11211327295_0eda6085c1_z.jpg" width="455" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;Heroine, thy name is &lt;a href="http://www.gillianlynne.com/" target="_blank"&gt;Gillian&lt;/a&gt;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/9118727268320673291/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=9118727268320673291' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/9118727268320673291'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/9118727268320673291'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/12/whoa.html' title='Whoa. '/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-5153636758879444707</id><published>2013-12-03T14:19:00.001-08:00</published><updated>2013-12-10T09:44:18.446-08:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='life story'/><title type='text'>tiny (and not so tiny) dancers</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11193030154/" title="IMG_1429 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_1429" height="500" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5516/11193030154_8943512311.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;I hope everyone had a lovely break with their families, friends, pets, lovers, all of the above, some of the above, rainbows from above. I also hope that none of you came home to a house full of rat traps and invoices for things you weren't prepared to pay for this month. Womp. The good news is, I think our rat issue has been resolved once and for all and I got to hang out in our attic for the first time since we bought the house and it's huge, albeit full of dead pigeons and holes, and now I'm all pumped to turn it into some kind of creative loft space for the kids as soon as we can afford to turn it into some kind of creative loft space. (Right after we tear up the kitchen floor and re-do the broken chimneys and OH HEY, living in an old house that needs work is WORK. I love this house but there is literally a hole the size of a person in the laundry room because of a leak and everything needs to be repainted and sometimes it feels extremely overwhelming. Not unlike life, for sure, but still... Homeownership, you are a mixed bag.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Anyway, I'm sure you guys are super interested in reading about rat traps and pigeon carcasses but I'm going to move on to jollier waters aka 4 Non Blondes as interpreted by Bo, Revi and Larry Woolf last week at my parents' house:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="360" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/26WbPUGH0jk?rel=0" width="480"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;In the words of Bo. "Again!"&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And, yes, again.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Lots of again.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;There was much music to be had this past week. Maybe it's always that way but it felt especially music-y these past few days, my sister on her flute and Hal on piano, my grandparents waltzing around the living room while my parents busted out with newly minted ballroom dancing skills. (They're taking ballroom/swing dancing lessons which is very cute.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11193183006/" title="photo (18) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (18)" height="500" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3783/11193183006_feb6a21a1b.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Dancing is my happy place and watching people dance is my other happy place because it is impossible &lt;i&gt;not &lt;/i&gt;to&lt;i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;be happy doing either. I dare you to get up and dance right now and wear a frown. It's impossible. Even with a rat trap under your desk.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Bo is on a whole other level with dancing. I have been so frustrated with her lately, going back and forth between &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/11/rock-her-gypsy-soul.html" target="_blank"&gt;crying/laughing/wanting to applaud her every move/put her in a cage &lt;/a&gt;so that I can, you know, acknowledge the other kids. (Bo is now climbing out of her crib at naptime/bedtime, climbing into Revi's crib, waking her up, climbing out of Revi's crib, taking all of the clothes out of the dresser and then leaving the room and being like, "Oh hey, mom. What's up?") &amp;nbsp;Last night Hal and I were watching TV on the couch and suddenly Bo was standing in the hallway waving at us. At 10pm.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"I got out," she simply said.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I wanted to scream.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And laugh.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;(I did both.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Yesterday I put on music as a sort of babysitter. I had to get dinner ready and Bo wanted to "touch the boiling water" so I put on some music and was like, "There. Go... dance."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And she did.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And I couldn't stop watching her. I never can. She comes alive in this new way when the music's on. She LIVES that action. It's almost as if she knows what to do with her body when there's a melody. &lt;b&gt;She listens.&lt;/b&gt; She follows and leads and communicates in a way she doesn't during normal business hours.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;This morning my mom sent me the following which is a transcript from &lt;a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/ken_robinson_says_schools_kill_creativity.html" target="_blank"&gt;Sir Robinson's TED talk&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;blockquote class="tr_bq"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/ken_robinson_says_schools_kill_creativity.html" target="_blank"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Gillian Lynn – a choreographer who did Cats, and Phantom. They had lunch and he asked “how’d you get to be a dancer?” She said when I was in school, in the 30′s I was really hopeless, and the school wrote to her parents and said she has a learning disorder.&amp;nbsp;Probably now they’d say she had ADHD. But this was the 30′s, and it hadn’t been invented, it wasn’t an available condition. People weren’t aware they could have that.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote class="tr_bq"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/ken_robinson_says_schools_kill_creativity.html" target="_blank"&gt;&lt;i&gt;So she went to see this specialist, in this oak paneled room, and she sat on her hands while this woman talked to her mother about all the problems Gillian was having at school. And at the end of it, (she was 8), the doctor went and sat next to her, and said “I’ve listened to all the things that your mother has told me, and I need to speak with her privately, we’ll be right back.”&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote class="tr_bq"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/ken_robinson_says_schools_kill_creativity.html" target="_blank"&gt;&lt;i&gt;As he went out the room, he turned on the radio that was sitting on his desk. and when they got out of the room, he said, “just watch her”. Soon as they left, she was on her feet, moving to the music. He said to her mother “Mrs, Lynn,Gillian isn’t sick, she’s a dancer. take her to a dance school”. &lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote class="tr_bq"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/ken_robinson_says_schools_kill_creativity.html" target="_blank"&gt;&lt;i&gt;She did.&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote class="tr_bq"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/ken_robinson_says_schools_kill_creativity.html" target="_blank"&gt;&lt;i&gt;“I went to this room, and it was full of people like me. People who couldn’t sit still, people who had to move, to think. They did ballet, tap, jazz, everything.”&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote class="tr_bq"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/ken_robinson_says_schools_kill_creativity.html" target="_blank"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Then she got a wonderful career at the royal ballet, graduated, founded her own company, met Andrew Lloyd Weber, and has been responsible for some of the most amazing ballets in history...&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote class="tr_bq"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/ken_robinson_says_schools_kill_creativity.html" target="_blank"&gt;Someone else might have put her on medication, and told her to calm down...&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And, well, it made me cry. And then it made me get on the Internet and sign Bo up for dance class.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;My sister is getting her doctorate in flute performance and is amazing so I had to share the following video, too, even though I butchered the song c/o a thousand tiny videos I filmed and then strung together. (Music is Oiseaux Tendres by &lt;a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Rivier" target="_blank"&gt;Jean Rivier &lt;/a&gt;and &lt;a href="http://www.presser.com/composers/info.cfm?Name=SAMUELZYMAN" target="_blank"&gt;Samuel Zyman&lt;/a&gt; flute sonata.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;Soul sisters with hair of curl, one of flute, the other twirl:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/_aEYkmm1rlM?rel=0" width="560"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;To all the tiny (and not so tiny) dancers in the house, shine on!&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11194248004/" title="photo (24) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (24)" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2859/11194248004_7eb4fe4cb5_z.jpg" width="426" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;my grandparents, Milt &amp;amp; Betty&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11194190023/" title="photo (21) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (21)" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7437/11194190023_f87f104225_z.jpg" width="427" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11194055985/" title="photo (20) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (20)" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7431/11194055985_b7b9d78a28_z.jpg" width="426" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;(Rodent free, if possible.)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/5153636758879444707/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-4075696047502388380</id><published>2013-12-02T13:23:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2013-12-02T22:47:25.687-08:00</updated><title type='text'>#mykindofholiday = making it up as we go</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;The following video is sponsored by Target. Thanks, Target!&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11177539954/" title="unnamed by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="unnamed" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3830/11177539954_f212bb5430.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;We are not very holiday tradition-y. We light the menorah every night, the kids open little Hanukkah gifts, fall asleep playing with them, and then for Christmas we celebrate at my parents' house. (This year we had big plans to purchase our first "holiday" tree but then decided it would be too much with the &lt;strike&gt;little ones&lt;/strike&gt; Bo. Maybe next year?)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Anyway, when asked to participate in this campaign and come up with something "my kind of holiday -y" I was royally stumped because I don't really do anything traditional this time of year which I kind of feel bad about. I mean, we drink hot chocolate and watch White Christmas and read The Polar Express every other night but other than that... yeah, no. These halls are not decked. This kitchen does not smell of fresh baked gingerbreadpeople. Not that we don't decorate in our way and/or bake the occasional cookie. We do things this time of year, I'm just not sure what exactly.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;And that's what I ended up going with for this little video project of ours. &lt;i&gt;Our&amp;nbsp;kind of holiday? &lt;/i&gt;Making it up as we go along/figuring it out together, as a family of six googly-eyed cottonballs.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;script src="//player.ooyala.com/v3/ZjhhNWJlMGIzNDk2N2RjOTE4NDE2MTk2"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div id="ooyalaplayer" style="height: 380px; width: 550px;"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;script&gt;OO.ready(function() { OO.Player.create('ooyalaplayer', 'YxYm9yaDo4CT3AtMv00THQtxtQS8QC7e'); });&lt;/script&gt;&lt;noscript&gt;&lt;div&gt;Please enable Javascript to watch this video&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/noscript&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;i&gt;How about you guys? Any special traditions? Lack thereof?&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b style="font-style: italic;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;/i&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/4075696047502388380/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=4075696047502388380' title='1 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/4075696047502388380'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/4075696047502388380'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/12/mykindofholiday-making-it-up-as-we-go.html' title='#mykindofholiday = making it up as we go'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>1</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-64370200223613339</id><published>2013-12-01T09:14:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2013-12-01T09:14:45.954-08:00</updated><title type='text'>red, green, blue and white</title><content type='html'>&lt;i&gt;The following post is written by &lt;a href="http://victorialoustalot.com/" target="_blank"&gt;Victoria Loustalot&lt;/a&gt;, friend and author of &lt;a href="http://www.amazon.com/This-How-You-Say-Goodbye/dp/1250005205" target="_blank"&gt;This is How You Say Goodbye&lt;/a&gt;, a memoir about &lt;a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/19/fashion/19love.html?pagewanted=all&amp;amp;_r=0" target="_blank"&gt;the father she always loved but never really knew&lt;/a&gt;. Thank you, Victoria, for writing a beautiful book and so generously sharing your story, here.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;  &lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;***&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11097102626/" title="#2 Book Cover by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="#2 Book Cover" height="800" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3714/11097102626_7333639d35_c.jpg" width="530" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;I don’t remember &lt;a href="http://www.worldaidsday.org/" target="_blank"&gt;World AIDS Day&lt;/a&gt;. Not as a kid, though I know now it was around then. It began years before I was born and I grew up in Northern California, a   beautiful speck of earth that was no doubt first in line to take up the World AIDS Day   banner and wave it with abandon. Northern Californians love to save the day. A   good victim helps and AIDS had plenty of those, especially in the Bay Area. I should know. My   dad was one of them.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;He told my mother he was gay and HIV positive on Mother’s Day, 1989. I had   just turned four. He eventually developed full-blown AIDS, and we watched his life shrink until it was no bigger than his bed and the few feet to the   bathroom. He committed suicide when I was ten.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Somewhere in my childhood I must have participated &amp;nbsp;in World   AIDS Day. Lit a candle. Sang a song. But I have no memory of such activity, and I   suspect that’s because I could never reconcile this international day of tribute and   solidarity with the AIDS that was living in my house, killing my father. The importance of an   international conversation about AIDS was lost on me; I didn’t see how candles and   songs could help my family. I was no activist.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Awhile after my father died, friends of my mother invited us   to their home for dinner. Their adult son joined us, another one of AIDS’   victims--all bones in a t-shirt that may have fit once but now made him look lost and very small. I felt enormous beside him, yet he was surprisingly energetic – with more vim than anyone else at the table. Any energy my mother and   I had, we fed to our grief. And her friends, well, they were caregivers. Their energy   belonged to their son. On him, though, energy was jittery. He was never still. He   beckoned and brandished with his arms outstretched. Jumped from the table for   this. Then that. Motion constant. But he didn’t eat. Much later, I realized he must   have been on a whole medicine cabinet’s worth of AIDS cocktails. I didn’t meet him   that night; I met the harsh, violent drugs he was taking.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;When we left, he ran out after us. We were already in the car--seat belts tight   against our chests, my mother’s fingers curled around the emergency brake.   He came to my window and I opened it. He leaned in and I was near enough to the   sores on his face to kiss them. So close, that all I could see was skin. In his hand was a string of beads, primary colors: red, green,   blue, white. He could have been my father.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;“I’ve been making these. I want you to have this one.”&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;He placed it in my open hand and when I looked down I saw that he had   given me not only the beads, but also a small AIDS ribbon, which must have been   new because its edges were sharp and its red shade brilliant. I wasn’t sure what to   say to this man I hardly knew. I was only a kid. But I did know just barely enough to   recognize that sometimes a simple thanks will do. Thank you. I closed the window and he stood there watching our car roll down the driveway. He didn’t wave but he   wore a slight, calm smile. It was the first time all night I had seen him   still.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;That night, before I went to bed, I pinned the ribbon to my backpack, and   the next morning, before I left for school, I tied his string of beads around my neck,   choker style. I wore those beads every single day for years, until one day their string   broke and the beads slipped off my neck in a rush, spilling down the front of my   shirt and onto the sidewalk below, spinning in too many different directions at once.   The ribbon lasted longer, but it did, in time, lose its brilliance and began to fray.   The fray crept up and up until eventually it was just a red knot, and then one day   I noticed even that was gone. The last threads had fallen off somewhere along the   way.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;I never saw him again. He died soon after our meeting. Still, it is his face   – not my father’s – that appears each time I see the AIDS ribbon. With his small,   handmade gift he pointed me in the direction of action. He made an activist out of   me.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #473a32; font-family: Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; line-height: 19.1875px; text-align: start;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://aids.gov/news-and-events/awareness-days/world-aids-day/"&gt;&lt;img alt="World AIDS Day. December 1." class="right" src="http://aids.gov/images/world_logo1.gif" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;For more on World Aids Day, which is today, go &lt;a href="http://www.aids.gov/" target="_blank"&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;- VL -&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #473a32; font-family: Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; line-height: 19.1875px; text-align: start; white-space: pre-wrap;"&gt;&lt;noscript&gt;&lt;div  &lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;VL&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/noscript&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/64370200223613339/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=64370200223613339' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/64370200223613339'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/64370200223613339'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/12/red-green-blue-and-white.html' title='red, green, blue and white'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-2814857528391878331</id><published>2013-11-28T09:47:00.000-08:00</published><updated>2013-11-28T09:48:40.660-08:00</updated><title type='text'>Thank you + Much love</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11079929005/" title="photo (16) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (16)" height="500" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5524/11079929005_7e02b7a110.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;I know it's cliche to be thankful today but I wanted to take a moment to thank you all for reading. Whether you stop by this site daily or weekly or once every few months, I'm grateful for your time and support, your insight and emails and kind words and retweets and all of the things you do and have done to support me, my family and this blog through the years.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Our house is currently infested with rats. (&lt;a href="http://instagram.com/p/g_IK24LAYh/" target="_blank"&gt;We thought they were mice&lt;/a&gt;. They are not mice.) And &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2012/12/lice-and-other-bugs.html" target="_blank"&gt;last Thanksgiving all of us had lice.&lt;/a&gt; (My rhymes are legit.) And yesterday, while on the phone with Hal who had just finished sussing the rat stitch with the exterminators, I was like OH MY GOD THANKSGIVING HATES US but then I realized, nah, this is just life doing what it does best - serving us a giant piece of shithappens pie on gratitude's birthday.&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Bon Appetit, humans. Grace &lt;/i&gt;(crotch grab)&lt;i&gt; this!&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;And that's just what we'll do. Because what a blessing to have a house in the first place, you know? What a blessing to have hair and a house and lice combs and exterminators who will deal with these kinds of things because I am hopeless when it comes to killing things and Hal is kind of also. #peace&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;...Anyway, all of this to say, hi. Life is wild and you are wonderful and on behalf of all of us, thank you. Sending love and light, health and happiness today and always.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11080022836/" title="photo (15) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (15)" height="500" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2864/11080022836_028729a162.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/11079937485/" title="photo (14) by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo (14)" height="500" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7395/11079937485_8485ac7763.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;xoxoxo,&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Us&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/2814857528391878331/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html'
