scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='mix tape'/><title type='text'>184/100</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;My friend &lt;a href="http://www.somewherebetweenmovie.com/" target="_blank"&gt;Linda&lt;/a&gt; shared&lt;a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D-eVF_G_p-Y" target="_blank"&gt; this Suli Breaks video&lt;/a&gt; after I shared &lt;a href="http://www.wired.com/business/2013/10/free-thinkers/all/" target="_blank"&gt;this link&lt;/a&gt; on facebook. It's amazing. Please watch.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/D-eVF_G_p-Y?rel=0" width="560"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"We were taught to always follow when Miss... led. The irony."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And this:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/y_ZmM7zPLyI?rel=0" width="560"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;ALL of Suli's videos are wonderful and thought-provoking and can be found/subscribed to &lt;a href="http://www.youtube.com/user/sulibreezy" target="_blank"&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;. His website is &lt;a href="http://www.celebuxzz.com/" target="_blank"&gt;here.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;184. I Will Not Let an Exam Result Decide my Fate &amp;amp;&lt;br /&gt;Why I Hate School but Love Education by:&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.celebuxzz.com/" target="_blank"&gt;Suli Breaks&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;***&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;(I've started a Rethink Education Pinterest page, &lt;a href="http://www.pinterest.com/girlsgonechild/rethinking-education/" target="_blank"&gt;here,&lt;/a&gt; for those interested. I am terrible at tagging and am working on getting better organized here on GGC. In the meantime, I'm using Pinterest as a way to group specific topics. Much love, all.)&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/2040196694066170391/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=2040196694066170391' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/2040196694066170391'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/2040196694066170391'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/10/184100.html' title='184/100'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-8076245329541923068</id><published>2013-10-18T07:39:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2013-10-21T21:37:37.011-07:00</updated><title type='text'>Thank you for being a friend. </title><content type='html'>&lt;i&gt;I met Lauren and Molly back in 2003 &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2006/11/when-children-disappear_02.html" target="_blank"&gt;when I was working as a chat host for Starbright World &lt;/a&gt;(now the Starlight Foundation.) At the time, Lauren was&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2007/04/shenannygans-introducing-lauren.html" target="_blank"&gt;paralyzed from the waist down and up one of her arms&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;and Molly was in and out of hospitals as well.&amp;nbsp;Molly and Lauren, BFFs since I've known them,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;were regulars in the chat room when I started and &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2006/11/when-children-disappear_02.html" target="_blank"&gt;I spent five years chatting with them and other/kids and teens with chronic and terminal illness&lt;/a&gt;, all of whom were amazing. Molly and Lauren, though, were a team. There was something about their friendship, something so clearly karmic. It was something to behold. They were sisters. I&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;nseparable even though they lived thousands of miles away from each other. Molly regularly went to visit Lauren when she was bedridden and when Lauren recovered, and Molly was on the mend, both Lauren and Molly moved to LA.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;There are people who come into our lives with the kind of force that in a series of instants,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;changes our entire life perspective. For me that was&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;Lauren and Molly, Spencer and Nikki, Adam, Scarlett and Michael (BugMan!), Alyssa, Heather... &amp;nbsp;and countless others, all of whom removed the blindfold I didn't even realize I was wearing and showed&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;nbsp;me what it meant to BE ALIVE. To have a sense of humor about the things that made me afraid. They set me free. They taught me that death was not something to be afraid of and for that reason, neither was life and truly living it. If I have a parenting philosophy it comes from them, from spending my first three years as a parent surrounded by the most amazing kids and teens in the universe. Molly was one of them. She made all who knew her better. Stronger. More equipped to face life and to appreciate what it meant to be here.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;She filled the world with a light that keeps on...&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;Molly passed away in May. She was clever and silly, beautiful and loving and one of the toughest broads ever to exist. She carried her fists behind her eyes. Her storm behind her calm. And nobody knew her better than her best friend, Lauren, who wrote a post I am honored to share today, in memory of Molly and to promote&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="https://www.facebook.com/TheMollyPearceEakerFoundation" target="_blank"&gt;The Molly Pearce-Eaker Foundation&lt;/a&gt; a non-profit committed to spreading awareness about the importance of organ donation. Love and light to all.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;When we met, I was the sick one. I was seventeen and Molly was fourteen.&amp;nbsp;&lt;span style="text-align: center;"&gt;I was bedridden from a rare blood disease that paralyzed me for several years, and she was dealing with blood infections and kidney problems and a slew of other crap that no one should ever have to experience but she did, time and time again.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312659215/" title="us_Snapseed by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="us_Snapseed" height="360" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3718/10312659215_123afc390b.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: center;"&gt;We were members of an online community for kids with chronic illness. We just clicked, like old, familiar souls picking up where we left off. We talked on the phone and video chatted and she visited me often at home in Kansas.&amp;nbsp;She never saw my hospital bed, or my feeding pump, or my paralysis. She just hopped into bed with me and we watched scary movies and talked about boys and made plans. She was my best friend. She was my sister.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312659186/" title="4_Snapseed by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="4_Snapseed" height="360" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5520/10312659186_a70d2fe15d.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312600384/" title="blurry by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="blurry" height="360" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2817/10312600384_d1cc851131.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Eleven years later, we changed places. I was healthy. I was walking. And she was very sick. It was my turn to go to her. Molls had so many close calls over the years. She was born with her illness. Going to the hospital was as normal to her as going to school is for most kids. Accessing her central line was second nature, preparing medication and IV pumps and dressing changes were routine. And as much as it was a part of her, it didn’t define her. She made sure of that. She survived comas and two transplants and countless infections and surgeries, one death-defying stunt after another. I took it for granted that she would be okay. Surviving was just what she did.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312812713/" title="Molls 4-20 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="Molls 4-20" height="375" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7328/10312812713_a6f9cffbd3.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;In May, her mom called. She told me that this time was going to be different, and I needed to get to Omaha to be with her as quickly as possible. She had always been honest with me. “I never want either of you girls to be blindsided,” she always said. I still didn’t believe it could really be the end. It was never the end. It was always supposed to be the end and then she came back to us and it wasn’t.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I hopped into bed with her and held her hand and rested my head on her shoulder and I talked about the time we jumped the curb in Santa Monica in the middle of the night because we wanted to go to the beach. We ended up straddling the median before finally freeing ourselves. An actual entrance to the beach was like five feet away, but we didn’t notice that until we had already become criminals. And the time we went sledding with the ATVs, and the time we visited the haunted hotel where Stephen King wrote The Shining, and the time we locked Spencer out of the house and started screaming when he knocked on the window because we were afraid the real Spencer had been kidnapped and the window knocker was a Spencer imposter/serial killer. And the time we ate pie and it was my first food in five years, and the time we went to that pony show and Phoebe was bigger than most of the ponies, and the time we crammed four dogs into the Focus and the red dog was definitely trying to get us to careen off a cliff and we were like WHY DO YOU WANT TO MURDER US ALL, RED DOG? And the time, and the time, and the time…&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;I didn’t see the tubes or the medicines or the pumps. Just her. Just my best friend in the whole world. I sang “Thank You for Being a Friend.” The Golden Girls is our show. We planned to grow into adorable old biddies, adopt dogs and horses and alpacas and open Lauren and Molls Ranch Farm.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312608304/" title="hands by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="hands" height="500" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2876/10312608304_98775c1d63.jpg" width="499" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;A few days before we lost her, she married Corey. Her nurses and doctors transformed a conference room into a beautiful wedding chapel. Her doctor, Dr. Schaffer, gave her his grandmother’s pearls to wear on her wedding day. She looked beautiful. She looked happy. Everyone was so proud and so sad and so filled with love. I was her maid of honor. I told her that she would be mine when Steven and I get married, and she will, still. I know she will be there.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312806453/" title="love by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="love" height="458" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7353/10312806453_ba23b9a4e0.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;The morning she died, her friend, Nona, and I wandered around the hospital in a daze. I felt an overwhelming desire to talk to Dr. Shaffer and Molly’s nurses so we went up to the 5th floor. She spent the last seven months of her life on the 5th floor solid organ transplant unit and they loved her deeply. We hugged everyone and said goodbye. They paged Dr. Shaffer and he came right away. I asked him if he believed in “something after,” if he thought there was more to us than bones and brains and organs. He confidentially replied, “Of course! Yes. We are all atoms and molecules and energy. Nothing ever dies. We go back to where we came from and we are a part of everything.” According to a man of science who relies on proof and test results and measurable evidence to make informed life or death decisions on a daily basis, we’re all recycled and our energy echoes forever. I’ll take it.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312746665/" title="mollynecklace by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="mollynecklace" height="371" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5540/10312746665_a3ea7c0231.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Molly was about sharing, recycling, living and loving and taking one and passing it down. She gave radio and television interviews from her hospital room to help promote organ donation awareness up until the very end. Back in 2006 and 2007, she received a small bowel from a deceased donor, and her mom gave her a kidney. These gifts, as Molly always referred to them, bought her precious time. Instead of dying at seventeen, she moved to Los Angeles and lived close to me; went to school; rescued her beloved Great Dane, Lyla; saved a dog named Honey and helped find her a happy home; she stood up for me; she met her future husband; she went to Paris; she worked at a vet’s office; she made friends; she walked dogs; she had some close calls, survived them all; watched her mom marry her stepdad; she said goodbye to our friend and we cried and missed him but felt he would always be with us; she made funny videos with her brother; rode her horse, Bali; participated in Donate Life events; helped me eat a stranger’s cheesecake at a weird nightclub in Pacific Palisades that reminded me of Eyes Wide Shut, without all the naked people; indoor skydived (dove?) with Corey; dropped her iPhone in a crosswalk and watched a large, ill-timed bus run a yellow light and smash it into a million pieces and she went to parties and laughed a lot and flipped off shitty drivers and she loved her Corgi, Tegan, and her cat, Schmidt, and my service dog, (her God dog,) Phoebe, and we ate at Grub and Cha Cha Chicken and Urth and we were silly we laughed about things that only we understand and she got married and she lived really, really, really well. She packed ten lifetimes into those years.  She wanted everyone to have that chance.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;We used to say we were old souls meant for a different time. The 1920’s and 30’s, we thought, would suit us well, when people were a bit kinder and calmer and men held doors for ladies and ladies had cute Flappery accents and used words like “gams.” I think, mostly, we appreciated good manners. We sort of lived like twenty-something Golden Girls, spending Friday nights eating food and watching movies and taking a crap ton of medications and really appreciating a good night’s rest. We called ourselves “The Packard Hags.” We were going to own a Packard automobile one day, we said, and we would drive around town in big fancy hats and try out all different kinds of accents. After she passed away, I looked up the meaning of the Packard symbol. The hood emblem depicts a woman called the Goddess of Speed, flying, reaching, moving forward, quickly and with purpose.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312742995/" title="packard by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="packard" height="371" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2841/10312742995_9109ddb112.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312637425/" title="bedsmiles by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="bedsmiles" height="380" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3736/10312637425_ab1f838b38.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;i&gt;I’ll see you again, sister. I’ll keep my eyes and mind and heart open and I’ll pay attention. Thank you for climbing into my hospital bed, and for sharing yours with me. For you, I will take a moment, I will live with purpose, I will be grateful, I will be fierce.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312665366/" title="FierceMolls by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="FierceMolls" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7434/10312665366_1f3dc17191_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt; “Tonight, I hope all of you have a wonderful time, whether you go out or just chill at home. It's our chance to start all new. See big things happen and say, "2013 was a ______ year? Wasn't it!” Let's make that _____ &amp;nbsp;positive. Do things for others you wouldn't normally do, spend more time people you may not stop to think of much, stop to be in the moment, walk in other people's shoes for a second or two! Hopefully if people can shift their attitudes and be grateful and happy about just being healthy and being here, then more people awaiting transplants like me will get them and that will give more opportunity to make even MORE happy and grateful for what they got. Love you all so much! Xo”&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;- Molly, 12/31/12&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312675556/" title="mollybali2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="mollybali2" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3750/10312675556_fb0fe06d88_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;To learn more about Molly, her legacy, and how you can help assist transplant families waiting for the gift of life, please visit the &lt;a href="http://mollypearce-eakerfoundation.org/" target="_blank"&gt;Molly Pearce-Eaker Foundation&lt;/a&gt;. Visit &lt;a href="http://donatelife.net/" target="_blank"&gt;Donatelife.net &lt;/a&gt;to get the facts on organ donation, and to register to become a donor.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;P.S. Here's a silly short film I made with Molly and my servicedog, Phoebe. It's called Dr. Dog.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/sevPMuYMaG8?rel=0" width="560"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.radioconetwork.com/KRCNsite/rss/DLM/052813_DLM.mp3" target="_blank"&gt;&amp;nbsp;Molly radio interview- May 2013&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10312763736/" title="duds by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="duds" height="370" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7387/10312763736_c7b13a926d.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;- &lt;b&gt;Lauren -&lt;/b&gt;&lt;!--3--&gt;&lt;!--3--&gt;&lt;!--3--&gt;&lt;!--3--&gt;&lt;!--3--&gt;&lt;!--3--&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/8076245329541923068/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=8076245329541923068' title='1 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/8076245329541923068'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/8076245329541923068'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/10/thank-you-for-being-friend.html' title='Thank you for being a friend. '/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>1</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-3164592278487176980</id><published>2013-10-17T08:51:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2013-10-17T08:58:44.067-07:00</updated><title type='text'>Places to See: Griffith Park Observatory</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296291716/" title="photo-16 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-16" height="375" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7390/10296291716_a191cb4e41.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296281845/" title="photo-21 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-21" height="375" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7392/10296281845_ec2fc90b38.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296293765/" title="photo-17 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-17" height="375" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2827/10296293765_d7f4564c82.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10297342024/" title="photo by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo" height="375" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7408/10297342024_b593b6f9ba.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296285916/" title="photo-18 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-18" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3700/10296285916_e9451f8baa.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;We hadn't been to The Observatory as a family of six ever which is insane because Griffith Park is pretty close to where we live. I think because it's on a hill I feel like it's on the moon. I used to hike Griffith Park with the dogs all the time but that was a lifetime ago and now I feel like the hills are no place to raise a family.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Dumb because the hills are lovely.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The hills are ALIVE with the sound of lovely.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And the views of lovely.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And things pertaining to space.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The last time we spent a family day at The Observatory, Archer was two and Hal and I were talking about maybe having a second baby someday. I had forgotten about this conversation until we walked into the cafeteria area and it all rushed back and OH RIGHHHHT. This is where we had the talk.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Fable! This is where we talked about having another baby. About having a YOU," I told her.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;She shrugged, grabbed Bo's hand and off they went up the ramp toward the hazy skyline.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10297344244/" title="photo-1 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-1" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2813/10297344244_381dfdbcda_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296325355/" title="photo-7 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-7" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7337/10296325355_ccd29b13db_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296278086/" title="photo-20 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-20" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5543/10296278086_dbba775fa7_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296287165/" title="photo-19 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-19" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7426/10296287165_52057bdb3e_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296255016/" title="photo by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2886/10296255016_d268b27802_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296343255/" title="photo-2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-2" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7375/10296343255_8cc2ce0edc_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296304245/" title="photo-14 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-14" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5484/10296304245_36b6e50db4_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296198554/" title="photo-15 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-15" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5547/10296198554_d4d562c940_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296383343/" title="photo-25 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-25" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5547/10296383343_daef5297cf_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296234334/" title="photo-4 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-4" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5511/10296234334_981bfdfd81_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;For more on Griffith Park Observatory &lt;a href="http://www.griffithobs.org/" target="_blank"&gt;go here&lt;/a&gt;. It's great fun for the whole family.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296226924/" title="photo-6 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-6" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2831/10296226924_f54ae8718a_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296210634/" title="photo-11 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-11" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7299/10296210634_eb016f1449_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10296279115/" title="photo-22 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-22" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3777/10296279115_aaed12bd24_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/3164592278487176980/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=3164592278487176980' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/3164592278487176980'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/3164592278487176980'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/10/places-to-see-griffith-park-observatory.html' title='Places to See: Griffith Park Observatory'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-7156118410052404962</id><published>2013-10-16T08:48:00.001-07:00</published><updated>2013-10-16T08:48:34.014-07:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='eat well'/><title type='text'>Eat Well: African Peanut Soup</title><content type='html'>&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;The following post was written by my mom, WWW. Thanks, mom!&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10304224213/" title="photo-2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-2" height="375" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5499/10304224213_771642cd13.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;It’s pumpkin time once again, and the stores are brimming with all colors, sizes and shapes.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;It’s easy to forget that pumpkins are more than an ornament to set on a table or porch, and that during these few weeks leading up to Halloween and Thanksgiving we can buy all sorts of exotic pumpkins to eat.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;Several years ago, &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2010/11/eat-well-six-days-of-pumpkin.html" target="_blank"&gt;I wrote&amp;nbsp;a postabout the fairytale pumpkin&lt;/a&gt;, or Musquée de Provence—a French pumpkin that is delicious—bright orange, sweet and flavorful, and fabulous in sweet as well as savory recipes.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10304216943/" title="photo-9 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-9" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2878/10304216943_ea8778c378_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;There is a lot of food in a fairytale pumpkin so it can be a little &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2010/11/eat-well-six-days-of-pumpkin.html" target="_blank"&gt;overwhelming to know what to do with all of that pumpkin&lt;/a&gt;. If you aren’t cooking for a crowd, you can freeze the flesh either raw or cooked for up to 6 months so you can have plenty on hand for all of your favorite pumpkin recipes.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;I love squash soup and have shared several recipes here. But on Saturday my mom gave me a copy of her &lt;a href="http://heirloomgardener.com/" target="_blank"&gt;Heirloom Gardener Magazine &lt;/a&gt;with a recipe for African Peanut Soup, originally from &lt;a href="http://www.rareseeds.com/baker-creek-vegan-cookbook-and-bonus-seeds/" target="_blank"&gt;The Baker Creek Vegan Cookbook&lt;/a&gt;, and it sounded so delicious that I thought it would be a perfect time to cut open another Musquée de Provence. The pumpkin was perfect for this recipe as it is sweet and creamy.&amp;nbsp; I haven’t tried making it with sweet potatoes but I can’t imagine it could be better.&amp;nbsp; Larry and I devoured our soup, oohing and awing the whole time. It is unbelievably delicious, and after we were done, Larry rated it 12 stars out of 10. &amp;nbsp;(And with a salad and a slice of bread, it made for a very filling and satisfying meal.)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;I will freeze enough of my fairytale pumpkin to make a big pot of this soup for Thanksgiving, as I will definitely serve everyone a cup of it for a first course this year.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;b style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"&gt;African Peanut Soup&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;(from Emilee Gettle’s The Baker Creek Vegan Cookbook)&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;2 T coconut oil&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;1 large onion, chopped&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;1 lb (2 ½ cups) &lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;Beauregard sweet potatoes, butternut squash, or pumpkin (preferably fairytale) &lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;4 cloves garlic, chopped&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;1 tablespoon minced ginger&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;½ teaspoon chili flakes&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;4 cups vegetable stock&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;1 (14.5-ounce0 can diced tomatoes in juice&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;¾ cup creamy natural-style peanut butter (unsalted)&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;1 t salt (may not need if your broth has salt in it)&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;¼ cup chopped toasted peanuts&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;Chopped cilantro leaves&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"&gt;Heat oil in a medium saucepan over medium-high heat.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;Add onions and sweet potatoes or squash and cook until onions are translucent and sweet potatoes or squash begins to soften, 5-6 minutes.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10304016794/" title="photo-8 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-8" height="375" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5518/10304016794_600f04da3e.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Add garlic, ginger, and chili flakes, and cook, stirring, an additional 3 to 4 minutes.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10304097546/" title="photo-6 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-6" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3747/10304097546_01e6865266.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Add vegetable stock, tomatoes, peanut butter, and salt; bring to a boil, reduce heat, and cook until vegetables are tender, an additional 10-20 minutes.&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10304102856/" title="photo-1 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-1" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3752/10304102856_49b67548b0.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Remove from heat and cool slightly, then puree in batches in the blender (or use an immersion blender).&lt;span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10304020824/" title="photo-4 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-4" height="375" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7340/10304020824_6d1e15b240.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Divide among bowls and garnish with peanuts and cilantro.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/10304214723/" title="photo by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3812/10304214723_390e801059.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note:&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp; For anyone allergic to peanuts, you could substitute tahini (and a little cumin) for the peanut butter and, although it wouldn’t have the same flavor, I am sure it would also be delicious!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;Enjoy!&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;Love,&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;b&gt;WWW&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/7156118410052404962/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html'
