scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='mix tape'/><title type='text'>179/100</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9780016722/" title="tiny bubbles by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="tiny bubbles" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3764/9780016722_5801d62f88.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Hope everyone had a lovely weekend! We did a little celebrating, most of which I did in bed because I am a dead person of sickness. Big kids are home sick, too, so I'm going to take it down a few notches this week ie. no more epic birthday posts. (Not for another couple weeks, anyway.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;For now, here's a beaut of a song for all you lovers and friends. I'm a sucker for a sister trio, I am. And this one is beyond beyond.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/QBnhSAxzgSM?rel=0" width="560"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;179. Facing West by: &lt;a href="http://www.thestaves.com/" target="_blank"&gt;The Staves&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/5104304661422312402/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=5104304661422312402' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/5104304661422312402'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/5104304661422312402'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/09/179100.html' title='179/100'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-944571673945357352</id><published>2013-09-13T15:36:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2013-10-17T09:44:55.982-07:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='life story'/><title type='text'>II </title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9733173640/" title="photo-4 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-4" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5328/9733173640_4e32043e9d_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9729948593/" title="photo-3 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-3" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2828/9729948593_ed87dd9f0b_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9733171922/" title="photo by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3735/9733171922_0c40edb89d_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;My first tattoo was a Roman numeral II. The symbol for Gemini, twins - the sign of two faces and two selves and two opposing sides. Push apart, pull together, push apart. I was sixteen at the time, half the age I am now.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;Revi is yelling at Bo because Bo is trespassing through someone's garden.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Bo!" she says. "NO! Nonobobonono!"&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;But Bo is laughing. She is running around and falling on the steps and wedging herself between the giant tree as Revi throws her hands in the air because she cannot even BELIEVE that this is happening right now, until finally she has HAD IT and goes to where Bo is in the tree and grabs her by the back of the shirt.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Come on, Bobo. GO HOME."&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;And then Bo says, "NO!"&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;And Revi says, "YES!"&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;And they're full on yelling at each other in a stranger's yard until I have to intervene, pull them apart and carry them home, one under each arm, &lt;i&gt;nothing to see here, folks.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9734130949/" title="photo-10 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-10" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7331/9734130949_b9dc0fbdf5_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9734132081/" title="photo-9 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-9" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7296/9734132081_e88082f92a_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9737370914/" title="photo-7 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-7" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7372/9737370914_660ab9f471_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;The tattoo is terrible. It was done in someone's basement and it's on the small of my back and like all of my tattoos, was done with zero thought. But it's there and it always will be because I felt safe with that symbol. Gemini. Two faces. Two sides. Two selves. In opposition, in sync, in opposition, in sync...&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730433900/" title="IMG_5591 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5591" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3735/9730433900_52dcf451b3.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;And yet, "twins" always make me think of same. Same dress. Same hair. Same size. Twins make me think of twin day at school and how we did our hair the same and wore the same Peter Pan collared blouse with mint green shorts.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;And in that respect, I have spent the last two years struggling with the word because Bo and Revi are not in any way "twins."&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727202563/" title="IMG_5769 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5769" height="375" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5528/9727202563_e1f63ee103.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;I have become increasingly protective of their differences. Of their individuality. The balance. The conflict. The closeness. Their language and love for each other. The dynamic that occurs between partners who are two different heights, their differences, like puzzle pieces that fit together to form a... something.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727223309/" title="IMG_4350_2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4350_2" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5456/9727223309_578f95e689_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727222131/" title="IMG_4353_2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4353_2" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3675/9727222131_700766043a_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727225469/" title="IMG_4348_2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4348_2" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5492/9727225469_8c35651f49_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730455422/" title="IMG_4346 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4346" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5512/9730455422_b58cc46365_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727229475/" title="IMG_4342 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4342" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3827/9727229475_619d4dc1f2_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;Revi wraps her arms around her sister. Bo is crying and Revi wants to help. She runs back to the bedroom to grab Bo's blankie and Bo takes it and collapses in a pile of tears and sighs.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;Revi pats her on the back and then walks away and Bo looks up every now and then from her maddened sobs to make sure that Revi is... somewhere. Close. Next to her. Not doing anything without her.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;And then... she's up and fine and calling for Revi across the hall because whatever it is that &lt;i&gt;Revi&lt;/i&gt; is doing must be &lt;i&gt;awesome. &lt;/i&gt;(&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;And it is.)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;Bo wants what she's having and Revi wants to share. She wants to share her snacks and her books and her life with the sister she came into the world with.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;Bo does, too, but she won't admit it out loud. Instead she follows Revi around, begs to hang out in her crib with her before bed.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;Always sits down as close to her on the bench as she can without sitting on her lap.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730442002/" title="IMG_4958 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4958" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5492/9730442002_7c45379157_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727210713/" title="IMG_5128 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5128" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5452/9727210713_2e28eb2eb2_z.jpg" width="479" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730448920/" title="IMG_4621 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4621" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7343/9730448920_c490f4a91a_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"How old are you?" I ask.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Two!" Bo says holding up three fingers.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"One!" Revi says holding up one finger.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;Which is pretty much exactly what they are. Two going on still-a-baby. Two going on ready-for-third-grade.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727199401/" title="IMG_4176_2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4176_2" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7299/9727199401_2ac73c3c20_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Two year olds. Two years old. Times two. Terrible two double trouble and all of the things we say about two year olds. About having twins. About having two sides and two faces and being different in a world where individuals are compared to other individuals. Where distinction is a surprise. Where opposites are a marvel and symbolism is reserved for books and movies.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Today I am turning all of those things over in my head. I am opening the window and shaking out the dust. I am turning toward my "double trouble" "terrible two" year olds as they show me how beautiful and blessed this life is. I am thanking them. And then thanking them again. Separately. Together. As individuals. And as a team.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;br style="background-color: white; color: #222222;" /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;To be different than our sisters, our children and spouses and selves... to slip in and out of different roles, that is what gives our lives and the lives of others, purpose, meaning, joy. We are chameleons who determine our own shape-shift by understanding what sets us apart from the rest. Positive ions repel each other. It is the negative that the plus sign is attracted to. There must be something to that in people, too. The craving of conflict, of differences, the need to respect both the separation and the overlap. The yin and the yang and night and the day and the smile and the frown and the man and the woman and all of the other pairs that exist in nature. Opposites, most of them.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white;"&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9618316638/" title="IMG_4646 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4646" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7402/9618316638_7c1a667c92_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9438576818/" title="photo-18 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-18" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3692/9438576818_1f2dd33354_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9615103723/" title="IMG_3946 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_3946" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7442/9615103723_9ffbd57fed_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;I realize that comparing is something we all do. We all look like someone or remind someone of a person we knew once. I do it all the time. It's hard not to for some reason and I don't know why. But mothering twins has been an exercise in pointing out the differences in all of my children and all of my selves, both here on this blog and in real life, and then, doing what I can to celebrate them. Because that is what makes us interesting. Because every day my girls are compared to each other instead of being high-fived for being themselves.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;And it has made me think back to all of the times I have done the same thing.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727209159/" title="IMG_5326 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5326" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3778/9727209159_2befc94e18_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730425858/" title="IMG_5328 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5328" height="480" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7377/9730425858_f76303cd65_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;Perhaps it's because we all want to belong somewhere with someone. We want to find socks that match up and pairs to flip over and push aside in the memory game. We are programmed to recognize similarities and point to them. Stand in &lt;i&gt;that&lt;/i&gt; line. Go &lt;i&gt;this&lt;/i&gt; way.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;I have to push myself in different directions so I don't categorize and organize and project my experiences onto others. I have to pull myself away from the people I think I match with and get to know the stories that are different, the people who oppose, think differently, see differently.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;Having four children has taught me there are many ways to see the world and all of them have merit. That one can hold her fork in her left hand and eat just as well as her sister who holds her fork with her right. That the two can share a table. That we are all better off when they do. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;Because complementary colors look nothing alike.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;Bo's middle name means peace. Revi's means light. That first year I thought I gave them the wrong names. But I realize now that Bo's light is as much a part of Revi as Revi's peace is a part of Bo.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727234847/" style="clear: right; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-left: 1em;" title="IMG_3202 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_3202" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2807/9727234847_3e88f36746_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730443260/" title="IMG_4957 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4957" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7312/9730443260_53f70fdd38_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style="color: #222222;"&gt;The peace and the light are alive in both of them and all of them and all of us. The calm and the storm are one. Life is a drawer overflowing with pairs of mismatched socks. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222; font-family: inherit;"&gt;Like the ones Fable wears every day so that her feet are "more exciting."&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;Like the ones I wake up to in the morning and get to kiss goodnight before bed.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;i style="color: #222222;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;Good morning, sun. Good night, moon&lt;/i&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222;"&gt;.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727201053/" title="IMG_5899 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5899" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7362/9727201053_507eae10a8_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9438570726/" title="photo-21 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-21" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7342/9438570726_d241ddee37_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727192615/" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;" title="IMG_5668 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5668" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7435/9727192615_6e0d6f9fe9_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Happy second birthday, Reverie. Happy second birthday, Boheme. Thank you for two glorious years of lessons and love...&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730444278/" title="IMG_4848 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4848" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3810/9730444278_f35881d897_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left;"&gt;I marvel at your differences. I'm in awe of your bond.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730422314/" title="IMG_5609 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5609" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7285/9730422314_4e83d8c2cf_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727195685/" title="IMG_5590 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5590" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3671/9727195685_4e6d18d831_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9727207181/" title="IMG_5540 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5540" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5518/9727207181_88a9b8d06f_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;*** &lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/6242675203/" title="Hi. I have four children. HOW IN THE WHAT!? by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="Hi. I have four children. HOW IN THE WHAT!?" height="640" src="http://farm7.staticflickr.com/6058/6242675203_fd3e9c15ac_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9615109969/" title="IMG_3397 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_3397" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7402/9615109969_66195eece6_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9734129875/" title="photo by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7371/9734129875_40e4cfa8ca_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9734138413/" title="photo-3 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-3" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7343/9734138413_3beaa04617_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730437028/" title="IMG_5512 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5512" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3798/9730437028_9d488d8d6f_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9737932752/" title="photo by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo" height="480" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7305/9737932752_11340f998a.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9737369944/" title="photo-8 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-8" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7334/9737369944_0eca33fb9a_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/944571673945357352/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=944571673945357352' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/944571673945357352'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/944571673945357352'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/09/ii_13.html' title='II '/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-4189579996071826761</id><published>2013-09-12T13:26:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2013-10-14T21:38:57.487-07:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='eat well'/><title type='text'>eat well: the chronicles of lunchboxia </title><content type='html'>&lt;span style="font-family: inherit;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #1f497d;"&gt;This post is sponsored by Blue Diamond Almonds. Get Your Good Going with&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #1f497d;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #1f497d;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://facebook.com/bluediamondalmonds" style="color: blue;" target="_blank"&gt;Blue Diamond Almonds&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #1f497d;"&gt;!&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730024784/" title="photo-4 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-4" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3771/9730024784_1057dc6bfe_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Archer loves sandwiches. He loves hummus sandwiches to be precise and as a creature of habit, asks for them every day. It used to be turkey but he burned out on turkey and now he doesn't eat turkey anymore so it's hummus. Hummus sandwich + veggie (artichoke hearts are his jam) + strawberries + banana &amp;amp; cheese and crackers for snack. Every. Single. Day.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Fable, on the other hand, is not a creature of habit. She's down for the rotation. And very un-down for sandwiches, which has always made packing lunches for her frustrating.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;My kids don't eat much meat. Save for the odd fish stick and chicken tacos once a week, they get their protein elsewhere. Eggs. Nuts. Legumes of all kinds. Quinoa.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Archer eats a lot of hummus. Fable eats a lot of almonds. Bo and Revi eat a lot of both because they are going through a phase where they will eat most things you put in front of them unless they decide that food is the worst and then they smash it all in their hair.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But back to lunches.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;No meat for Fable. And no sandwiches. And no dairy because Fable is allergic to dairy. And something must be different every day because two socks should never be the same and I totally get that. It's like a puzzle, feeding her. It's like a puzzle feeding everyone, but Archer, Bo and Revi are easier puzzles. They are the huge-pieced puzzles with, like, ten pieces. Fable is a 1000 piece jigsaw. So this post is about her.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;When you find something healthy that your kids love, you should probably hold on for dear life to said healthy thing and that is what I'm doing with &lt;a href="http://bolaniandsauce.com/index.php?route=product/category&amp;amp;path=59_60" target="_blank"&gt;spinach Bolani&lt;/a&gt; which first entered our lives in 2010 c/o our local Farmer's Market and has not yet left. (There's also &lt;a href="http://bolaniandsauce.com/index.php?route=product/category&amp;amp;path=59_60" target="_blank"&gt;lentil, potato and pumpkin&lt;/a&gt; Bolani, all of which are delicious but Fable will only eat the spinach one and duh, it's spinach so of course I'm all in.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730027804/" title="photo-2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-2" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3818/9730027804_89855f82a2_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;ED: Each packet comes with two Bolanis which I then slice in half so one packet of Bolani = four lunches. I can dig it. (I buy these in bulk and eat them for lunch, too, with &lt;a href="http://bolaniandsauce.com/index.php?route=product/product&amp;amp;product_id=64" target="_blank"&gt;cilantro pesto&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href="http://bolaniandsauce.com/index.php?route=product/product&amp;amp;product_id=60" target="_blank"&gt;garlic mint cheese &lt;/a&gt;so that my breath smells nice and awesome.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9726796139/" title="photo-3 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-3" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5499/9726796139_b34a4fb0c0_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Along with the Bolani, which I cut into slices, I pack almonds (for her snack) fruit (always different), veggies (always different) and either a banana or healthy crackers, depending on the day.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730015376/" title="photo-12 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-12" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7316/9730015376_73355f5f7e_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730013962/" title="photo-13 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-13" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3698/9730013962_9f9b22d8d2_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;(I'm obsessed with these crackers, which is purely coincidental in that this is a post about the almonds by same company. I want to marry the nut thins and have flaxseed-hair babies.)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730012022/" title="photo by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2822/9730012022_0aac202dc5_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9726787857/" title="photo-10 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-10" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3758/9726787857_736001273e_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;ED: We were doing dairy-free cheese for a minute but then Fable decided it was disgusting. Here is a photo of Fable's lunch-foodstuffs which I snapped earlier in the week, all of which were a smashing success save for the edamame which Fable is no longer into because "frozen peas are better."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730020190/" title="photo-8 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-8" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3809/9730020190_ca269860f5.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Okay then. Frozen peas! Which will be nice and unfrozen by the time lunch happens. Or how about we just do cucumbers this week?&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: white; color: #1f497d;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9730021356/" title="photo-7 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-7" height="375" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5339/9730021356_9f54edca38.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Puzzles, man.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/4189579996071826761/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=4189579996071826761' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/4189579996071826761'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/4189579996071826761'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/09/eat-well-chronicles-of-lunchboxia.html' title='eat well: the chronicles of lunchboxia '/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-2074984236846446710</id><published>2013-09-11T14:11:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2013-10-17T09:44:27.159-07:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='life story'/><title type='text'>Last Days of One: Boheme </title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723191362/" title="IMG_9912 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_9912" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5467/9723191362_f3cb0ed3b9_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Bo, what are you doing?" I ask her as she pulls every book off the bookshelf and tries to read them all at once.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Shhhhhh," she says, holding her hand in front of her face.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;And then, hysterics. She is laughing like it's the funniest thing that has ever happened. Many books. One lap. Ha hahahahaha!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;"Bo. You shouldn't do that," I say.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;And then, somehow, I am laughing too. I am laughing and Archer and Fable are laughing and Revi is laughing and we're all standing around the bookshelf laughing.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;It's contagious, that's why.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;Her &lt;i&gt;Bo-ness &lt;/i&gt;is contagious.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;"You're in big trouble with this one," the NICU nurse told me, a few days after Bo was born.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"You're kidding, right? &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2011/09/boheme-reverie-one-week.html" target="_blank"&gt;All she does is sleep&lt;/a&gt;?"&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;It was a strange experience, hearing from a nurse about a child I had yet to truly know. For those first few days my only experience with Bo had been holding her while she slept. Feeding her while she slept. Loving her while she slept.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;She was the easiest baby that existed as far as I knew. Surely the nurse was wrong. Surely ALL the nurses were wrong.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"This one's a firecracker."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"She's a handful!"&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"Wild child."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;They were right, of course. And the first six months were by far my hardest as a parent. And even after, when the colic subsided and Bo relaxed, slept on her own, grew out of her screaming fits... Bo was... a force.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2011/10/birth-story-in-three-acts-one.html" target="_blank"&gt;It was Bo's bag of water that broke the night of the full moon&lt;/a&gt;. And every bag that surrounds her she has broken since. She is a wonder, a marvel, her energy palpable and challenging and vibrating on a frequency all her own.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;You know that scene in &lt;i&gt;Elf &lt;/i&gt;where Will Ferrell is drunk and doing &lt;a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yEySbwbTQFk" target="_blank"&gt;Lord of the Dance in the mailroom&lt;/a&gt;? That's Bo. Everywhere she goes. And it's amazing. And challenging. Bo is the mascot of everywhere we eat and shop. Her curly blonde ringlets and blue eyes differentiating her not only from her twin sister but from all of us.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723210392/" style="clear: right; display: inline !important; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-left: 1em;" title="IMG_4235 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4235" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3709/9723210392_bcf04ddc17_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;"Is she yours?" they ask.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"She doesn't look anything like the rest."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"That's because she isn't."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;She is Boheme. Boa. Bobo. Bo.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;She is the sun in human form, dancing without a song. She is strong like Ox, kicking soccer balls clear across the lawn, head bruised from somersaulting in her crib, foot bloodied, &lt;i&gt;she don't care&lt;/i&gt;. And yet, bull in china shop she is not. She is focused and inquisitive and so glad to be here on this earth. And it's contagious. That joy. That love. It's magnetic.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723195750/" title="IMG_7303 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_7303" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5489/9723195750_5429b72d2b_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9719984359/" title="IMG_4123_2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4123_2" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5522/9719984359_4d88c73212_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Bo is my open book. She wears her every thought and frustration and feeling on her face.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9719983131/" title="IMG_4178 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4178" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3774/9719983131_03cbe4210c_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;At all times.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9719979801/" title="IMG_4240 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4240" height="500" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3679/9719979801_9ecf85427b.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Bo is my helper. With her dustbuster and her sunscreen and how she drags the groceries through the lawn and when I say, "can I help you?" she always says no.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"NO. I CA DO IT!"&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And she can.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;(Most of the time, anyway.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9719986721/" title="IMG_0124 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_0124" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3794/9719986721_55645a7211_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;Bo is my rebel. The one I have to watch with eyes in the back of my head and chase after through the halls of museums and comfort after thirty minutes of tantrum. And when she's done she always finds me, collapses dramatically into my arms. &lt;i&gt;Oh woe!&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9719965647/" title="IMG_9887 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_9887" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2837/9719965647_c9efffc728_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Oh, Bo.&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;She is the smile that we all pass around the circle. She is the class clown sitting front row center ready to learn. And challenge. And speak without raising her hand.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723196738/" style="clear: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;" title="IMG_5564 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5564" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7437/9723196738_c56702bfa5_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723196738/" style="clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;" title="IMG_5564 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;I count to three before she lifts off. But before I get to three she's already gone. She's tearing through the house and through the yard and into oncoming traffic. She's saying hello to every face she sees. High-fiving babies in their strollers, sitting down beside old men on benches, painting the tree with a tube of red paint in her hand.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723203138/" title="IMG_5110 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5110" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5456/9723203138_1da2da46b6_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723204676/" title="IMG_4942 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4942" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5524/9723204676_98607ff1c9_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723213762/" title="IMG_1013 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_1013" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5323/9723213762_de02878a3d_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;/div&gt;She's a wild child, yes, but I'm &lt;i&gt;not in trouble with this one&lt;/i&gt;. &amp;nbsp;I'm in awe. I'm in hysterics. I'm in love...&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723194956/" title="IMG_9810 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_9810" height="500" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7362/9723194956_77417c95bd.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9719974163/" title="IMG_5113 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5113" height="500" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5344/9719974163_7774a7a39d.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;...And, yes, okay, a little sunburned. But that's just par for the course when you live with a sunbeam.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723198952/" title="IMG_5337 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5337" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3675/9723198952_e391510b23_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9723207792/" title="IMG_4693 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4693" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5339/9723207792_a0b180401b_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/2074984236846446710/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=2074984236846446710' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/2074984236846446710'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/2074984236846446710'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/09/last-days-of-one-boheme.html' title='Last Days of One: Boheme '/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-5440506507940357007</id><published>2013-09-10T16:46:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2013-10-17T09:45:27.443-07:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='life story'/><title type='text'>Last Days of One: Reverie</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9720230722/" title="IMG_5405 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5405" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2874/9720230722_40ac2cf03b_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;She squints and smiles with her eyes completely closed and then hides behind a leg or a wall or a giant hat that she stood on a chair to pull off a shelf in my closet.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"Up, up!' she says with a hat that falls backwards off her head and heels that tumble to the floor with a thud.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"Down, down," she says. "Shoes. Shoes."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9717014705/" title="IMG_5103 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5103" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5449/9717014705_74f1765441_z.jpg" width="479" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9720247522/" title="IMG_5102 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5102" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3772/9720247522_73e94a9c64_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9720246108/" title="IMG_5104 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5104" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2815/9720246108_b95b32e70d_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;The other day at my parents house, Bo and Revi burst into my parents bedroom and made a beeline for the tea party Fable and my sister had set up for Rachel's old American Girl dolls. I told them they could play as long as they were careful.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"RESPECT, my girls. These are not your dolls."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Bo lasted about three minutes before she started throwing everything and thinking it was hysterical so I had to escort her out of the room to have a tantrum in the hallway. But Revi stayed for, I don't know, thirty minutes? Forty five? She was careful with every cup. And hat. She used a carpet as a napkin and dabbed the cheeks of both dolls and sang "Moon River" except instead of saying "Moon River" she said "Bo Revi" which is how she sings the song.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;Bo, Reeeeeeviiiii.... &lt;/i&gt;and then stops. Sings it again. Stops... &lt;i&gt;Booooo, Revvvviii&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9717001507/" title="IMG_4830 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4830" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2812/9717001507_08676fd152_z.jpg" width="490" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Everyone says she looks like Fable and I can't see it. I mean, at certain angles in pictures, yes, but Revi is so completely herself. She is left handed in a sea of righties, always off in the distance doing her own thing, &lt;a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m-delqip9-0" target="_blank"&gt;little wing&lt;/a&gt;. Playing cars when everyone is playing dolls and dolls when everyone is playing cars. She isn't the type who feels left out. She's fine being last in line. She seems to prefer it, actually. She is strong and determined and whip smart, shouting at waves and jumping into water, dreaming away with invisible lightbulbs like balloons over her head. She likes to hold hands. With me and Hal and her sisters and Archer who she calls "Achoo." She is my baby. My cuddler. My littlest one who asks to be held and rocked before bed and says thank you when she means "you're welcome." Revi is generous with her toys and her snacks and her love. She blows kisses to all things, including signs and trees and must &lt;i&gt;muah &lt;/i&gt;every animal in every book she reads upside down. She goes about her days in my shoes and Fable's hats and dolls slung across her chest,&amp;nbsp;and in all my thirty-two years of life, never in the history of ever, have I seen a finer more detail-oriented tea party hostess.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="375" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/75AzdBoqU5g?rel=0" width="500"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;(Ever.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9717022147/" title="IMG_4396_2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4396_2" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2838/9717022147_42e09e7851_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9720232272/" title="IMG_5061 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5061" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7438/9720232272_b2af8e2afc_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9720254788/" title="IMG_3761 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_3761" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3778/9720254788_3c4da0971c_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9720240024/" title="IMG_5865 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5865" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5506/9720240024_d9b80b3f2b_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9720237166/" title="IMG_9831 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_9831" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3735/9720237166_739623a7bc_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9717018193/" title="IMG_4798 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4798" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5506/9717018193_11c1212eda_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9720227018/" title="IMG_1052 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_1052" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3728/9720227018_0866b9a906_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9720241482/" title="IMG_5514 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_5514" height="500" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7411/9720241482_6b881a97a0.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/5440506507940357007/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=5440506507940357007' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/5440506507940357007'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/5440506507940357007'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/09/last-days-of-one-reverie.html' title='Last Days of One: Reverie'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-8591771118681543635</id><published>2013-09-09T20:51:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2013-09-09T21:24:20.590-07:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='mix tape'/><title type='text'>178/100</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9712218703/" title="photo by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2825/9712218703_9810966236_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;We celebrated my dad's birthday over the weekend. My brother and sister flew in to surprise him and his brother and sister flew in to surprise him and my cousins and we all just sat together and went swimming and drank wine with wet hair and then everyone flew away two days later &lt;i&gt;whirwind weekend whoooosh.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;My aunt brought a DVD of old home videos of my dad and his siblings as babies. My grandparents dancing and kissing in wood-panneled rooms, my dad and his brother pushing their baby sister in her pram down the suburban sidewalks of Park Forrest, Illinois where my dad spent his formative years. (I kept thinking of &lt;a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2yoJFkzJUTI" target="_blank"&gt;The Wonder Years &lt;/a&gt;and Joe Cocker because that is what old home movies make me think about. Fred Savage and his fictional family.) And then, by 1960something the videos ended and old OLD videos of my Grandma and her siblings popped on the screen and we all gasped as we watched with our heads against each other's shoulders, empty glasses between our knees, collective awe.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9712519469/" title="photo-6 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-6" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3785/9712519469_d9cb8ffa78.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Surprisingly (to me, anyway) in 1928 babies acted like babies. Children acted like children. Teenagers made teenager faces. I expected to see these refined children all in a line in their pressed linen dresses which is what I think of when I think of "the good old days." I think of &lt;a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madeline" target="_blank"&gt;Madeline&lt;/a&gt; with all of the children in neat little lines, perfectly coiffed. And yet. It was just as chaotic then. In the most wonderful way it was exactly the same as it is now. More photogenic, perhaps, but the same crazy/wonderful.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;***&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The other day we were all watching&lt;a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089791/" target="_blank"&gt; Pee-wee's Big Adventure&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;and everyone was laughing at all of the same places and Archer said, "we all speak different languages but we all laugh the same."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;He was referring to his sisters who speak their own little language but find the same things hilarious but the truth in his statement resurfaced as we watched those home videos together. For some reason knowing that everyone laughs is kind of reason enough to live. I mean, on the worst days ever, &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2011/11/lolove.html" target="_blank"&gt;PEOPLE LAUGH&lt;/a&gt;. THAT IS A THING THAT HUMANS DO! THAT IS THE BEST NEWS.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9709959209/" title="photo-2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-2" height="375" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5450/9709959209_599096fc66.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;i&gt;my grandparents and cousin, Emily&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9709922709/" title="photo-23 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-23" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7367/9709922709_6cf7f9ac34_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;... and cousin, Sam&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;Generations have come and gone and we've all been relatively the same in the parenting department. We love our children the same as we did then. We take them on vacations when we can afford to. We try to make them laugh and we feed them with spoons and play with them in water when it's hot and bundle them up when it's cold and sometimes everyone gets along and sometimes nobody does and that is the way it's always been forever. Or at least since 1928.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Anyway.&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;Sing it, Joe.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/_wG6Cgmgn5U?rel=0" width="560"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;178. With a Little Help From my Friends, &lt;a href="http://www.cocker.com/us" target="_blank"&gt;Joe Cocker&lt;/a&gt; Version&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9709928665/" title="photo-19 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-19" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5508/9709928665_fec2866977_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9715547320/" title="photo-2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-2" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2812/9715547320_f4aa246173_z.jpg" width="479" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9712312927/" title="photo-4 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-4" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3670/9712312927_373c4c3be3_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9709946239/" title="photo-10 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-10" height="357" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7428/9709946239_5d5dfcc744.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9715548902/" title="photo-1 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-1" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3712/9715548902_1133a7bb04_z.jpg" width="479" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9712310069/" title="photo by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo" height="640" src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2893/9712310069_4d202baafc_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9712311625/" title="photo-5 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-5" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3784/9712311625_3803b82cd3_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9715545512/" title="photo-3 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-3" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3732/9715545512_ba9ed9fa01_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;***&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9712220621/" title="photo-1 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-1" height="640" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7441/9712220621_b2d941cb8b_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;GGC&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/8591771118681543635/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=8591771118681543635' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/8591771118681543635'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/8591771118681543635'/><link rel='alternate' type='text/html' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/09/178100.html' title='178/100'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image rel='http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail' width='32' height='24' src='http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/2048/193/1600/ggcsample.0.jpg'/></author><thr:total>0</thr:total></entry><entry><id>tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-18751784.post-8849163621787592164</id><published>2013-09-06T14:13:00.000-07:00</published><updated>2013-09-09T10:21:44.194-07:00</updated><category scheme='http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#' term='life story'/><title type='text'>Extraordinary</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9618346428/" title="IMG_3935 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_3935" height="640" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3816/9618346428_5972e2bd37_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;Today is my dad's 60th birthday. The look of complete contentment on Revi's face? Yeah, that's Papa for you. That's dad. That's Larry Woolf, senior citizen. (Seniors rule.)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;I'm going to share a story about Larry Woolf, here, right now, because I don't write about my dad nearly enough and today he is officially a man.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;My dad is a physicist. He lives and breathes physics. Growing up, we spoke two different languages and because I couldn't speak physics, and he couldn't speak teenager, we didn't say much to each other save for "Hi. I love you. Please stop yelling at your mom?" and "Dad, could you give me and my friends a ride to this party and then pick us up, like, super late from the party. Like, three blocks away?"&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Anyway. I ended up taking physics senior year in high school because it meant a lot to my dad and I owed him after all of those rides. And also because I adored him. (Duh.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Unfortunately, I was not a natural.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And my teacher was not a natural, either. And? He hated me. I mean, I was kind of the worse so I can't really blame him but also, the man was a terrible teacher. Sorry but he just was.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;And I'm not just saying that because he gave me an F. &amp;nbsp;(I came very close to not graduating because of said F and finally, because I begged in tears, my teacher agreed to pass me with a D-. )&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;My dad was furious.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Not at me but at the system. Science education was a disaster and my dad was going to do something about it. He was heartbroken that I hated science so much. So? The year I graduated high school my father threw every free moment of his time towards science education reform. And for the last fifteen years, that is what he's been doing. At night when he comes home from work, he rewrites curriculum and edits and writes letters and organizes conferences to repair and reform science education. That's his hobby. His extracurricular activity. His resume is made up of dozens of published papers and events he's chaired and talks he's given and also? "Being an extra on &lt;a href="http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_bang_theory/" target="_blank"&gt;The Big Bang Theory.&lt;/a&gt;"&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;He had big plans for acting when he was little. He was cast as the lead in the school musical in middle school and then had to drop out because he was diagnosed with thyroid cancer. He had to have his thyroid removed and was never able to sing a note again. I mean... he sings, sure. But he never had a voice. (Even my mom, who has been music directing theatre since I was a baby, was unable to cast my dad in any of her musicals because of his inability to carry a tune. Also, my mother's heart is made of stone. Just kidding.)&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;My point being, my dad, who always wanted to act and sing and be on stage, never got the chance. And never once complained about it or felt sorry for himself. Every now and then he'd bring it up but always in a "oh well, that's just life" kind of way.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But passive Larry Woolf is not. So when he was put in charge of booking speakers for the American Physics Society in Anaheim, California, he decided to ask one of the EPs of his favorite show (The Big Bang Theory) to appear on his "Educating and Exciting the Public about Physics" panel.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0695080/" target="_blank"&gt;Bill Prady&lt;/a&gt; said yes.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Months later, after coming and joining my &lt;a href="http://meetings.aps.org/Meeting/APR11/SessionIndex2/?SessionEventID=150249" target="_blank"&gt;dad's panel at APS&lt;/a&gt;, my dad posed for a photo with Prady and the two of them exchanged a few words. My dad brought &lt;a href="http://www.sci-ed-ga.org/modules/materialscience/color/materials.html" target="_blank"&gt;his posters&lt;/a&gt;, the ones about color theory (the primary colors are NOT red, yellow and blue, they are cyan, magenta and yellow) that he had made. They talked educational modules and Prady asked if my dad could send some of his posters along and then my dad asked if he could be an extra on the show maybe someday. &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Like, put it out there, nothing to lose, &lt;i&gt;what do you say, Prady?&lt;/i&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;A few weeks later, my dad was given his assignment. He would appear as a background artist on episode 1 of Season 5. He was to spend a day on set and appear as a "background artist" for two scenes. The posters he had had sent over? All over the walls. All of them.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;He called me. He called my brother. He called my sister. He asked my kids to get on the phone. This was it. This was major. This was his television debut.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Two years have passed and my dad's episode is still alive and well on the TiVo -- a moment my dad relives from time to time on the big screen TV he purchased for the occasion. A dream that wound its way around and up and down and underneath and through a hole and then out and then through and then up again. And, no he didn't have a speaking part. And if you didn't know to watch for Larry, you might not have caught him.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But he killed it up there. He ROCKED that Members Only jacket in the background of the cafeteria scene.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;"It was one of the greatest days of my life," he said. &amp;nbsp;"I got to be an actor. Kind of..."&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9662779407/" title="Untitled by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="Untitled" height="480" src="http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7338/9662779407_9fe7c6a1d5_o.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left;"&gt;(Larry Woolf, upper right corner. Blue jacket. Mustache. Show-stealer.)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: left;"&gt;Lately I've been thinking a lot about chance. About our lack of control over certain areas of our lives and our ability to take control of them later on. About life lists harkening back to all of the things we were too scared or too limited to try when we were younger. How better off we are for asking questions and failing physics and picking up the phone in ways we will never be fully aware of until much later.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;My dad was a teenager on the phone that night after the shoot. He spoke a mile a minute all about how he brought all of these shirts to wear and they were all wrong and the guys had to find him this old blue members only jacket that was kind of way too small but it was all they had and everyone said he did a great job and that maybe he would come back and do another episode and the guys all seemed so nice and his posters were up on the wall and it was the greatest day ever pretty much.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;This story doesn't have an ending. My dad will likely never retire and if he does, he will continue to work as hard as he does now trying to improve science education. Coming up with experiments to do&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2013/03/a-few-quick-things.html" target="_blank"&gt;with children&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;and teenagers. He will continue his outreach, trying to make physics something that young people WANT to study. And maybe he will get into acting someday. Or maybe it was just&lt;i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;that one time in the cafeteria in The Big Bang Theory. Because I think, for him, that might have been enough to close that door.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;My dad may be a physicist who lives and breathes physics but he's a father and husband and grandfather first, an educator &lt;a href="http://www.girlsgonechild.net/2006/03/laughter-will-get-you-everywhere.html" target="_blank"&gt;and rapper &lt;/a&gt;and friend and brother and son and human being and extra. And he lives and breathes all of that, too. He lives and breathes and exhales and inhales and jumps and puts his hands in the air and says "heyaaaaa" to all of that action.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/8629798608/" title="photo-2 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="photo-2" height="375" src="http://farm9.staticflickr.com/8385/8629798608_ee8f82ac9c.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;I was crazy fortunate &amp;nbsp;to grow up with this man as my example of what real men are like. Loving fathers, partners, who work tirelessly to make the world a better place. Who love without judgement and do not try to "lock up their daughters." (My dad used to hug boys when they came to pick me up for dates. Even when he knew they'd likely break my heart.) Who fight the good fight for the people they love and host screening parties for their Big Bang Theory background artist debut(s). My dad is the whole package of wonderful and interesting and kind and quirky. He has never judged anyone, (including himself) for doing what they love and being who they are. And I am so grateful for every moment and story, every lesson and laugh I've experienced as my father's daughter. I'm grateful for every story, lesson, laugh my children get to experience with him as well.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9682693921/" title="IMG_7152 by girlsgonechild, on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_7152" height="375" src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3720/9682693921_2e6d69caef.jpg" width="500" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Happy Birthday, Dad. We love you so much it &lt;i&gt;physic&lt;/i&gt;ally hurts.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Bec&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</content><link rel='replies' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.girlsgonechild.net/feeds/8849163621787592164/comments/default' title='Post Comments'/><link rel='replies' type='text/html' href='http://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=18751784&amp;postID=8849163621787592164' title='0 Comments'/><link rel='edit' type='application/atom+xml' href='http://www.blogger.com/feeds/18751784/posts/default/8849163621787592164'/><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' title='Extraordinary'/><author><name>GIRL'S GONE CHILD</name><uri>http://www.blogger.com/profile/07130764109593048451</uri><email>noreply@blogger.com</email><gd:image type='text'>The Month in Moments: August</title><content type='html'>&lt;div style="text-align: center;"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/girlsgonechild/9618309664/" title="IMG_4109_2 by on Flickr"&gt;&lt;img alt="IMG_4239" height="640" src="http://farm6.staticflickr.com/5523/9615086633_170d95e5e1_z.jpg" width="480" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a
